Yeah dark beaches.. The fetus was delivered in the bathroom. So, unless you can prove that the baby was alive when put in the trash can, the trash can is an irrelevant issue. How she discards the dead fetus has no bearing on the case.

So, the question is, was the fetus born alive. The medical examiner's tests were not reliable. And if born alive, did it survive at least a few minutes. Because at least that much time is needed to get to the hospital. Lack of 911 call does not make her a murderer.

I normally would be supportive of equally blaming men but not in this case. The woman does not deserve the punishment. But, unless the man cheated saying that he cannot get her pregnant, he has no culpability in this case as far as I can see so far.

Yes, if a woman ends her pregnancy in 6th month, it should not be a crime. A pregnancy/child has much more impact on a woman and is life altering for her. Some may not able to handle the consequences. Further, female hormones plays a wreck on their behavior. Most of the times, it is not black and white as you make out to be.

Going back to your car example, what if the woman tried to end her life because she is depressed and felt life was hopeless? What if the mother walked into the river with her child because she is in Iraq and knows ISIL captures her child, they will rape and enslave the child for the rest of her life?

Examples are easy. Being in other's shoes is harder.

Unfortunately, this is a state case. A federal pardon is not possible. Only the state Governor can pardon and we know his outlook by his recent actions. Also, as much as I do not want the woman to spend time in jail, a pardon implies her conviction was valid and can be used as an example in future such prosecutions.

I know a woman who lost her parents in a car crash when she was 18--and she had 3 younger sisters and a brother. Along with an aunt, she raised up those siblings herself and went to school at night. After going through all this, including refusing to go to sleep until every last sibling had come home safely after parties, proms and dates, she decided that was her mom 'duty' and wanted a child-free life afterward. Ultimately, she became an emergency room doctor. I have never met a more generous, loving, responsible person. There is usually always deep subtext to people's decisions which we should respect before harshly judging.

My life is not my own in the most wonderful, remarkable,  and transformative way I could never have imagined! As mom to a 16month old, I put on hold my doctoral studies to be home and yes it has been exhausting and challenging in all ways you mention. I am returning to my work now, but when i look into her face, the delay was worth it. The proposition of raising another human being who will carry on our progressive drive, tolerance, environmental protectivist spirit, drive to learn, thirst for knowlege, and who will thrive on applying that knowledge to making the world a better place made the decision an easy one for my spouse and I. The rewards are so much greater than the tradeoffs, and if friends who are firefighters and nurses and busdrivers and flight attendants and teachers and school counselors are all having children and making it work financially, you will also be ok.

A bit unfair to Auriemma. Summitt unilaterally ended the rivalry, and it's primarily on Warlick to repair the relationship. But she's got troubles of her own, overseeing the first Tennessee senior class to fail to make a single final four in decades. They were in with a shot, but self-destructed down the stretch. Auriemma, I have no doubt, would be happy to have every top program on the schedule. He's playing South Carolina as they rose to be a top program. After a year off as Notre Dame jumped to the ACC, they were back on UConn's schedule, and UConn ripped them in South Bend. Stanford? Check. Baylor?
Even if teams duck UConn, playing in a terrible conference has given Auriemma the chance to hone his team's concentration, and to lengthen the bench, at least during the interminable regular season. But when they were challenged for the first time in months, by a fearless and blisteringly hot Dayton team, his top four players played every single minute until the game was well in hand, 37 minutes in.
Coach McCallie of Duke may have dropped UConn, but that's to the detriment of her team, not Auriemma's. And you can take it to the bank that his team heard all about unbeaten Kentucky losing in the men's semifinal tonight.

So for 25% of the time in the past 16 years, UConn with 4 championships has outperformed the Dukes, Kentucky's and Louisville's of the world. Even without getting many of the all-Americans.  This speaks volumes of what good coaching can do. I hope Geno has a chip on his shoulder as I do - and will stick around for a decade and more.  I hope Kevin O. has the same fire and success that Calhoun had. The hockey teams are rising.  Baseball is rising. Perhaps it's time for the world of sports to recognize that UConn, minus the football program - is the nation's elite sports university. 'When a pro team moves to the back of the draft, there is nothing fair about it. that system serves to punish excellence and reward incompetence. in what way is that fair?'

It's not about fairness in the sense that you mean. It's about fairness in terms of each team being given the best chance of competing for a championship down the road. To do otherwise--reward success and punish failure--would be to essentially destroy competitiveness within a sport, and ultimately the sport itself. Just imagine the Patriots or the Packers getting a top1-5 pick every year--ridiculous if you want competition. Obviously, the college game of basketball is set up differently, and winners tend to get better players and perpetuate their success. That's a competitive issue, but teams like Wisconsin are living proof that top-flight home-grown athletes that are well-coached can beat the most physically gifted.

We got a fairness problem here with college sports dynasties. When a pro team wins a championship, they move to the back of the draft. But when a college team wins, the reverse happens -- all the best high school players decide they want to go there.

So Duke, Kentucky and Louisville divide up what -- 95%? more? -- of the MacDonald's all American high schoolers on the men's side and then are able to create the closest thing to a pro team, with their coaches actually earning more than pro coaches because, afterall, they've created the biggest business on campus with using their free labor pool of "student athletes."

(Duke's coach, whatsachefsky, earns 5 million plus!)

The same dynamic happens on the womens side with the likes of Connecticutt, Stanford, Tenn.

Why, it's as unfair as giving billionaires the biggest tax breaks. We wouldn't do that, would we?

What can we do about it? Nothing, but cheer on Wisconsin.

As for Geno not rushing to play Tennessee, after Pat Summit called it off on the basis that having Maya Moore visit ESPN in Connecticut was unethical, is it any surprise he holds a grudge? He schedules all the other top teams in the regular season.

Where in the Constitution is a Muslim's beard protected in prison? Where in the Constitution is man required to remove his hat when entering a bank lobby and not a woman and her chador? Where in the Constitution does it say that a Christian must work on Sunday or be fired from his job? Where in the Constitution is the right stated for a prisoner to receive gender reassignement surgery? Where in the Constitution is the protection upheld for conscientious objectors who have taken their religious view as a route to pacifism? Where in the Constitution is pornography identified as free speech?

I could do this all day, my friend.

I know that the Conservatives were the folks who started thumping on the Constitution, and they have this coming to them. But I also know that the Constitution was written by men who believed that some things didn't need to be said.

Maybe it's time for a new Constitution. After all, it was written two hundred years ago by slave-owning men. Why should we trust such an outdated document with our country's future?

Very much of a 'straw man' column.  The hypothetical journalist offers stereotypical questions, Douthat provides supposedly well-thought out answers. I'd be far more impressed if Douthat submitted to a thoughtful debate with someone from the other side of the political spectrum and addressed the Constitutional issues in depth.
